json.text: Well, I'm an economist and in the late 90s I was working for the FCC, the Federal Communications Commission in the United States.
And there was a series of mergers that took place between the big internet backbones of the time.
Now a lot of them don't exist or they were bought up at MCI, WorldCom, UUNet, Sprint.
And so I got involved in looking at the antitrust implications of those mergers, but that really led me into the whole area of internet interconnection,

because what was interesting at the time, and is still true today, is that these companies operated fiber optics and wires across the country, and when they sent telephone calls over them, they were regulated, and when they sent internet traffic over them, they weren't.
And we wanted to make sure it stayed that way throughout the mergers.
And so I really got interested in how these guys could interconnect without regulation on the mergers.
That's one of the topics I've stuck to.
Then I went into consulting, did a number of interesting projects for the Internet Society, and then I joined last August as the chief economist.

Well I think that really it's again this interconnection issue that when I was at the FCC I wrote this paper called The Digital Handshake that really talked about how this interconnection could work and self-regulate.
On the Internet using the same wires as they were regulated on, as I said.
But really, it was one of the first papers that really documented why the FCC and why one shouldn't regulate this.
And I've really been building on that.
And even as the system has evolved over the last 12, 13 years, it's really stayed the same.
And so I'm quite proud of that one because it really showed how the Internet could work without regulation.
I think it's remained true today.
Well, I think it's overall sunny, but some snowed in clouds, I guess.
Clearly there's some issues, but I think there's general optimism that things are looking good and there's bright sunny days ahead.
I think it's more hopes than concerns.
I think that the really exciting thing, we're about to hit 3 billion users by one count.
It should happen in June.
So that's an amazing number, but that's still about 40% of the world.
So I think that one of the things the Internet Society stands for is the Internet is for everyone.
And I think that with the mobile technology we're really going to hit four or five billion soon and I think that's the really exciting prospect that keeps me going.
Well, I think we have to address the privacy and security issues that have come up.
I think that, you know, so much of what we're doing in our lives, we're putting on the Internet.
And we have to be sure that the things that we want to remain private remain private.
When we want to be anonymous, it remains anonymous.
So I think that we need a simple and easy way to protect our information and make sure it stays safe.
As we increasingly put our lives online, as we increasingly interact with our banks, with our government, with everything online.
So I think that that's going to have to be addressed, and I'm sure it will be, and the Internet Society will play its part.

j'avais parlé avec Christiane, bien sûr, pour Merteuil.
Beaucoup d'écoles ?
Tous les conservatoires partout, et par les autres moyens aussi.
Et comme ça, on a trouvé une troupe splendide.
Exactement, oui.

En tout cas, c'est une belle initiative du Théâtre de l'Atelier d'avoir accueilli... Oui, et j'adore ce théâtre.

J'ai rencontré Laura Pelz, manager en fait et on a discuté le truc c'était plutôt vite fait et on a répété là-bas en 2008 on a fait quelque chose pour la tournée de Good Canary parce que j'étais obligé de refaire un peu le casting et tout ça parce qu'on n'a pas eu tellement de monde sur la tournée mais c'était Vite fait.

C'est extrêmement bien joué, la mise en scène est très bien faite et franchement c'est émouvant et on rigole.

Franchement, je recommande.
Un très beau respect du texte.

Merci.

00:00.000 --> 00:04.000
A film by Jean Malkovich

00:04.000 --> 00:06.000
This is Paris.

00:06.000 --> 00:08.000
It's a pleasure to welcome in this video

00:08.000 --> 00:10.000
John Malkovich.

00:10.000 --> 00:12.000
Hello.

00:12.000 --> 00:14.000
So, after Goode Canary,

00:14.000 --> 00:16.000
the play for which you won the Molière Award

00:16.000 --> 00:18.000
for the staging,

00:18.000 --> 00:20.000
we find you at the Théâtre de l'Atelier

00:20.000 --> 00:22.000
for a staging of

00:22.000 --> 00:24.000
the theatrical adaptation

00:24.000 --> 00:26.000
of Christopher Hampton

00:26.000 --> 00:28.000
Des Liaisons Dangereuses.

00:28.000 --> 00:30.000
Have you been thinking about it for a long time,

00:30.000 --> 00:32.000
to do this staging for this creation?

00:32.000 --> 00:34.000
Yes, absolutely.

00:34.000 --> 00:36.000
I read the play,

00:36.000 --> 00:38.000
I think it was in 1924,

00:38.000 --> 00:40.000
it's been a long time.

00:40.000 --> 00:42.000
And I've always thought

00:42.000 --> 00:44.000
of doing a staging.

00:44.000 --> 00:46.000
Maybe not exactly

00:46.000 --> 00:48.000
in the same way

00:48.000 --> 00:50.000
that we do now,

00:50.000 --> 00:52.000
but because

00:52.000 --> 00:54.000
at the beginning,

00:54.000 --> 00:56.000
we had other ideas for staging

00:56.000 --> 00:58.000
and all that.

00:58.000 --> 01:00.000
But in fact,

01:00.000 --> 01:02.000
I'm very happy

01:02.000 --> 01:04.000
that we didn't do

01:04.000 --> 01:06.000
as we had planned

01:06.000 --> 01:08.000
and that

01:08.000 --> 01:10.000
we did the play

01:10.000 --> 01:12.000
as we do now.

01:12.000 --> 01:14.000
Because at the beginning,

01:14.000 --> 01:16.000
it was totally different?

01:16.000 --> 01:18.000
Totally different.

01:18.000 --> 01:20.000
Completely different.

01:20.000 --> 01:22.000
Much heavier.

01:22.000 --> 01:24.000
Much heavier.

01:24.000 --> 01:26.000
And a lot of other things.

01:26.000 --> 01:28.000
At the very beginning,

01:28.000 --> 01:30.000
we visualized the characters,

01:30.000 --> 01:32.000
the actors

01:32.000 --> 01:34.000
that we would like to see

01:34.000 --> 01:36.000
in this or that role.

01:36.000 --> 01:38.000
Who did you think of at the very beginning

01:38.000 --> 01:40.000
for Valmont or Madame de Merteuil?

01:40.000 --> 01:42.000
We thought of...

01:42.000 --> 01:44.000
Since I had

01:44.000 --> 01:46.000
loved working with Christian

01:46.000 --> 01:48.000
and Réalise

01:48.000 --> 01:50.000
on Good Community,

01:50.000 --> 01:52.000
at the beginning,

01:52.000 --> 01:54.000
I had talked to Vincent Cassel

01:54.000 --> 01:56.000
for Valmont,

01:56.000 --> 01:58.000
and of course

01:58.000 --> 02:00.000
for Merteuil.

02:00.000 --> 02:02.000
Yes.

02:02.000 --> 02:04.000
I had talked to

02:04.000 --> 02:06.000
Ludwine Saunier,

02:06.000 --> 02:08.000
I had talked to Marion Cotillard,

02:08.000 --> 02:10.000
among others.

02:10.000 --> 02:12.000
But in the end,

02:12.000 --> 02:14.000
we decided to do it

02:14.000 --> 02:16.000
like that,

02:16.000 --> 02:18.000
with the young unknown actors.

02:26.000 --> 02:28.000
We have a casting manager,

02:28.000 --> 02:30.000
Justine,

02:30.000 --> 02:32.000
who started doing

02:32.000 --> 02:34.000
her investigations

02:34.000 --> 02:36.000
and her research.

02:36.000 --> 02:38.000
A lot of schools?

02:38.000 --> 02:40.000
Yes, like all the conservatories

02:40.000 --> 02:42.000
everywhere,

02:42.000 --> 02:44.000
and by other means too.

02:44.000 --> 02:46.000
And...

02:46.000 --> 02:48.000
And like that,

02:48.000 --> 02:50.000
we found

02:50.000 --> 02:52.000
a splendid troupe.

02:52.000 --> 02:54.000
Exactly, yes.

02:54.000 --> 02:56.000
You put...

02:56.000 --> 02:58.000
You had pulled

02:58.000 --> 03:00.000
from all the people

03:00.000 --> 03:02.000
that you had seen,

03:02.000 --> 03:04.000
you had seen at least 300,

03:04.000 --> 03:06.000
300 amateur actors

03:06.000 --> 03:08.000
or young actors,

03:08.000 --> 03:10.000
and you had to filter

03:10.000 --> 03:12.000
about fifteen of them.

03:12.000 --> 03:14.000
Was the choice difficult?

03:14.000 --> 03:16.000
Terrible difficult.

03:16.000 --> 03:18.000
And that's not a reflection

03:18.000 --> 03:20.000
on the people

03:20.000 --> 03:22.000
that I had chosen,

03:22.000 --> 03:24.000
obviously,

03:24.000 --> 03:26.000
because they were the ones who were chosen.

03:26.000 --> 03:28.000
There were a lot of choices,

03:28.000 --> 03:30.000
and very good choices.

03:30.000 --> 03:32.000
And it was a decision

03:32.000 --> 03:34.000
that I don't regret at all.

03:34.000 --> 03:36.000
But...

03:36.000 --> 03:38.000
Still,

03:38.000 --> 03:40.000
it was a difficult choice.

03:40.000 --> 03:42.000
Just to bring me a letter,

03:42.000 --> 03:44.000
but that wasn't the case

03:44.000 --> 03:46.000
when I finally understood

03:46.000 --> 03:48.000
why he was there.

03:48.000 --> 03:50.000
It was too late.

03:50.000 --> 03:52.000
What did you do?

03:52.000 --> 03:54.000
What did you think of the film?

03:54.000 --> 03:56.000
Did you have a new translation?

03:56.000 --> 03:58.000
Yes, yes.

03:58.000 --> 04:00.000
Okay.

04:00.000 --> 04:02.000
Completely.

04:02.000 --> 04:04.000
Okay.

04:04.000 --> 04:06.000
Nothing was added?

04:06.000 --> 04:08.000
Yes.

04:08.000 --> 04:10.000
But this is part of the adaptation.

04:10.000 --> 04:12.000
That means

04:12.000 --> 04:14.000
we didn't take

04:14.000 --> 04:16.000
the last scene

04:16.000 --> 04:18.000
of Christopher Hampton's

04:18.000 --> 04:20.000
real play,

04:20.000 --> 04:26.000
And the last one, I don't know, three or five minutes, something like that,

04:26.000 --> 04:29.000
which doesn't exist in the play,

04:29.000 --> 04:36.000
and which is either part of Christopher Hampton's screenplay,

04:36.000 --> 04:42.000
where he made the screenplay for a film with Kim Perkins,

04:42.000 --> 04:45.000
or which comes from the novel.

04:45.000 --> 04:49.000
In any case, it's a great initiative of the Atelier Theatre to have you here.

04:49.000 --> 04:53.000
Yes, and I love this theatre.

04:53.000 --> 04:58.000
I met Laura Pelz, who is the owner,

04:58.000 --> 05:04.000
and Veronique, who is the manager.

05:04.000 --> 05:09.000
And we discussed things, it was rather quick,

05:09.000 --> 05:14.000
and we rehearsed there in 2008 or 2009,

05:14.000 --> 05:15.000
something like that.

05:15.000 --> 05:19.000
Yes, for Good Canary's tour,

05:19.000 --> 05:24.000
because I had to redo the casting,

05:24.000 --> 05:28.000
because we didn't have that many people on the tour.

05:30.000 --> 05:34.000
But it was quick.

05:34.000 --> 05:35.000
Okay.

05:35.000 --> 05:39.000
And it's a very nice theatre.

05:39.000 --> 05:42.000
It's extremely well played, the staging is very well done,

05:42.000 --> 05:44.000
and frankly it's moving, and we laugh,

05:44.000 --> 05:45.000
because there's already something to laugh about.

05:45.000 --> 05:47.000
The script is great too,

05:47.000 --> 05:50.000
with the use of objects every day in an old set,

05:50.000 --> 05:52.000
frankly, I recommend it.

05:52.000 --> 05:55.000
A very nice respect for the text,

05:55.000 --> 05:59.000
a good energy for young actors,

05:59.000 --> 06:02.000
and thank you John Malkovich for giving young actors the chance,

06:02.000 --> 06:04.000
because it's not always the case.

06:04.000 --> 06:07.000
Taking advantage of his notoriety to get to know new actors,

06:07.000 --> 06:10.000
it's a success.

06:10.000 --> 06:12.000
It was very interesting when we rewrote,

06:12.000 --> 06:14.000
because it changed a lot about the film.

06:14.000 --> 06:17.000
It's nice to be able to make the comparison between the two,

06:17.000 --> 06:20.000
and I find that the humorous side is well played,

06:20.000 --> 06:21.000
it's super nice.

06:21.000 --> 06:24.000
Do you know what a business committee is?

06:24.000 --> 06:25.000
Yes.

06:25.000 --> 06:27.000
Okay, but I'm asking the question,

06:27.000 --> 06:31.000
because this video is intended for the members of the business committee,

06:31.000 --> 06:35.000
which brings the audience to the theatre in particular.

06:35.000 --> 06:38.000
So to conclude, I would say,

06:38.000 --> 06:41.000
what happens to my members of the business committee,

06:41.000 --> 06:43.000
it happens at the Théâtre de l'Atelier,

06:43.000 --> 06:45.000
it's called Les Liaisons Dangereuses,

06:45.000 --> 06:48.000
it was signed for the staging by John Malkovich,

06:48.000 --> 06:53.000
and it's one of the best shows at the Parisian theatres right now.

06:53.000 --> 06:55.000
Thank you very much, thank you John,

06:55.000 --> 06:58.000
for this time spent with us.

06:58.000 --> 06:59.000
Thank you.
